trans-unit.source: troubleshooting access problems in windows powershell web access
trans-unit.target: troubleshooting access problems in windows powershell web access

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting Access Problems in Windows PowerShell Web Access
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting Access Problems in Windows PowerShell Web Access

trans-unit.source: Updated: June 24, 2013
trans-unit.target: Updated: June 24, 2013

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.source: The following table identifies some common problems that users might experience when they are attempting to connect to a remote computer by using Windows PowerShell Web Access, and includes suggestions for resolving the problems.
trans-unit.target: The following table identifies some common problems that users might experience when they are attempting to connect to a remote computer by using Windows PowerShell Web Access, and includes suggestions for resolving the problems.

trans-unit.source: Problem
trans-unit.target: Problem

trans-unit.source: Possible cause and solution
trans-unit.target: Possible cause and solution

trans-unit.source: Sign-in failure
trans-unit.target: Sign-in failure

trans-unit.source: Failure could occur because of any of the following.
trans-unit.target: Failure could occur because of any of the following.

trans-unit.source: An authorization rule that allows the user access to the computer, or a specific session configuration on the remote computer, does not exist.
trans-unit.target: An authorization rule that allows the user access to the computer, or a specific session configuration on the remote computer, does not exist.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access security is restrictive; users must be granted explicit access to remote computers by using authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access security is restrictive; users must be granted explicit access to remote computers by using authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: For more information about creating authorization rules, see Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access in this guide.
trans-unit.target: For more information about creating authorization rules, see Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access in this guide.

trans-unit.source: The user does not have authorized access to the destination computer.
trans-unit.target: The user does not have authorized access to the destination computer.

trans-unit.source: This is determined by access control lists (ACLs).
trans-unit.target: This is determined by access control lists (ACLs).

trans-unit.source: For more information, see “Signing in to Windows PowerShell Web Access” in Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console, or the Windows PowerShell Team Blog.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see “Signing in to Windows PowerShell Web Access” in Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console, or the Windows PowerShell Team Blog.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell remote management might not be enabled on the destination computer.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell remote management might not be enabled on the destination computer.

trans-unit.source: Verify that it is enabled on the computer to which the user is trying to connect.
trans-unit.target: Verify that it is enabled on the computer to which the user is trying to connect.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see “How to Configure Your Computer for Remoting” in about_Remote_Requirements in the Windows PowerShell About Help Topics.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see “How to Configure Your Computer for Remoting” in about_Remote_Requirements in the Windows PowerShell About Help Topics.

trans-unit.source: When users try to sign in to Windows PowerShell Web Access in an Internet Explorer window, they are shown an Internal Server Error page, or Internet Explorer stops responding.
trans-unit.target: When users try to sign in to Windows PowerShell Web Access in an Internet Explorer window, they are shown an Internal Server Error page, or Internet Explorer stops responding.

trans-unit.source: This issue is specific to Internet Explorer.
trans-unit.target: This issue is specific to Internet Explorer.

trans-unit.source: This can occur for users who have signed in with a domain name that contains Chinese characters, or if one or more Chinese characters are part of the gateway server name.
trans-unit.target: This can occur for users who have signed in with a domain name that contains Chinese characters, or if one or more Chinese characters are part of the gateway server name.

trans-unit.source: To work around this issue, the user should install and run Internet Explorer 10, and then perform the following steps.
trans-unit.target: To work around this issue, the user should install and run Internet Explorer 10, and then perform the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Change the Internet Explorer Document Mode setting to IE10 standards.
trans-unit.target: Change the Internet Explorer Document Mode setting to IE10 standards.

trans-unit.source: Press F12 to open the Developer Tools console.
trans-unit.target: Press F12 to open the Developer Tools console.

trans-unit.source: In Internet Explorer 10, click Browser Mode, and then select Internet Explorer 10.
trans-unit.target: In Internet Explorer 10, click Browser Mode, and then select Internet Explorer 10.

trans-unit.source: Click Document Mode, and then click IE10 standards.
trans-unit.target: Click Document Mode, and then click IE10 standards.

trans-unit.source: Press F12 again to close the Developer Tools console.
trans-unit.target: Press F12 again to close the Developer Tools console.

trans-unit.source: Disable automatic proxy configuration.
trans-unit.target: Disable automatic proxy configuration.

trans-unit.source: In Internet Explorer 10, click Tools, and then click Internet Options.
trans-unit.target: In Internet Explorer 10, click Tools, and then click Internet Options.

trans-unit.source: In the Internet Options dialog box, on the Connections tab, click LAN settings.
trans-unit.target: In the Internet Options dialog box, on the Connections tab, click LAN settings.

trans-unit.source: Clear the Automatically detect settings check box.
trans-unit.target: Clear the Automatically detect settings check box.

trans-unit.source: Click OK, and then click OK again to close the Internet Options dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click OK, and then click OK again to close the Internet Options dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Cannot connect to a remote workgroup computer
trans-unit.target: Cannot connect to a remote workgroup computer

trans-unit.source: If the destination computer is a member of a workgroup, use the following syntax to provide your user name and sign in to the computer: <workgroup_name>\<user_name>
trans-unit.target: If the destination computer is a member of a workgroup, use the following syntax to provide your user name and sign in to the computer: <workgroup_name>\<user_name>

trans-unit.source: Cannot find Web Server (IIS) management tools, even though the role was installed
trans-unit.target: Cannot find Web Server (IIS) management tools, even though the role was installed

trans-unit.source: If you installed Windows PowerShell Web Access by using the Install-WindowsFeature cmdlet, management tools are not installed unless the IncludeManagementTools parameter is added to the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: If you installed Windows PowerShell Web Access by using the Install-WindowsFeature cmdlet, management tools are not installed unless the IncludeManagementTools parameter is added to the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For an example, see “To install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets” in Install and Use Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: For an example, see “To install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets” in Install and Use Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: You can add the IIS Manager console and other IIS management tools that you need by selecting the tools in an Add Roles and Features Wizard session that is targeted at the gateway server.
trans-unit.target: You can add the IIS Manager console and other IIS management tools that you need by selecting the tools in an Add Roles and Features Wizard session that is targeted at the gateway server.

trans-unit.source: The Add Roles and Features Wizard is opened from within Server Manager.
trans-unit.target: The Add Roles and Features Wizard is opened from within Server Manager.

trans-unit.source: The Windows PowerShell Web Access website is not accessible
trans-unit.target: The Windows PowerShell Web Access website is not accessible

trans-unit.source: If Enhanced Security Configuration is enabled in Internet Explorer (IE ESC), you can add the Windows PowerShell Web Access website to the list of trusted sites, or disable IE ESC.
trans-unit.target: If Enhanced Security Configuration is enabled in Internet Explorer (IE ESC), you can add the Windows PowerShell Web Access website to the list of trusted sites, or disable IE ESC.

trans-unit.source: You can disable IE ESC in the Properties tile on the Local Server page in Server Manager.
trans-unit.target: You can disable IE ESC in the Properties tile on the Local Server page in Server Manager.

trans-unit.source: The following error message is displayed while trying to connect when the gateway server is the destination computer, and is also in a workgroup: <strong>An authorization failure occurred.
trans-unit.target: The following error message is displayed while trying to connect when the gateway server is the destination computer, and is also in a workgroup: <strong>An authorization failure occurred.

trans-unit.source: Verify that you are authorized to connect to the destination computer.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you are authorized to connect to the destination computer.

trans-unit.source: When the gateway server is also the destination server, and it is in a workgroup, specify the user name, computer name, and user group name as shown in the following table.
trans-unit.target: When the gateway server is also the destination server, and it is in a workgroup, specify the user name, computer name, and user group name as shown in the following table.

trans-unit.source: Do not use a dot (.) by itself to represent the computer name.
trans-unit.target: Do not use a dot (.) by itself to represent the computer name.

trans-unit.source: Scenario
trans-unit.target: Scenario

trans-unit.source: UserName Parameter
trans-unit.target: UserName Parameter

trans-unit.source: UserGroup Parameter
trans-unit.target: UserGroup Parameter

trans-unit.source: ComputerName Parameter
trans-unit.target: ComputerName Parameter

trans-unit.source: ComputerGroup Parameter
trans-unit.target: ComputerGroup Parameter

trans-unit.source: Gateway server is in a domain
trans-unit.target: Gateway server is in a domain

trans-unit.source: Server_name\user_name, Localhost\user_name, or .\user_name
trans-unit.target: Server_name\user_name, Localhost\user_name, or .\user_name

trans-unit.source: Server_name\user_group, Localhost\user_group, or .\user_group
trans-unit.target: Server_name\user_group, Localhost\user_group, or .\user_group

trans-unit.source: Fully qualified name of gateway server, or Localhost
trans-unit.target: Fully qualified name of gateway server, or Localhost

trans-unit.source: Server_name\computer_group, Localhost\computer_group, or .\computer_group
trans-unit.target: Server_name\computer_group, Localhost\computer_group, or .\computer_group

trans-unit.source: Gateway server is in a workgroup
trans-unit.target: Gateway server is in a workgroup

trans-unit.source: Server_name\user_name, Localhost\user_name, or .\user_name
trans-unit.target: Server_name\user_name, Localhost\user_name, or .\user_name

trans-unit.source: Server_name\user_group, Localhost\user_group or .\user_group
trans-unit.target: Server_name\user_group, Localhost\user_group or .\user_group

trans-unit.source: Server name
trans-unit.target: Server name

trans-unit.source: Server_name\computer_group, Localhost\computer_group or .\computer_group
trans-unit.target: Server_name\computer_group, Localhost\computer_group or .\computer_group

trans-unit.source: Sign in to a gateway server as target computer by using credentials formatted as one of the following.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to a gateway server as target computer by using credentials formatted as one of the following.

trans-unit.source: Server_name\user_name
trans-unit.target: Server_name\user_name

trans-unit.source: Localhost\<em>user_name
trans-unit.target: Localhost\<em>user_name

trans-unit.source: .\<em>user_name
trans-unit.target: .\<em>user_name

trans-unit.source: A security identifier (SID) is displayed in an authorization rule instead of the syntax user_name/computer_name
trans-unit.target: A security identifier (SID) is displayed in an authorization rule instead of the syntax user_name/computer_name

trans-unit.source: Either the rule is no longer valid, or the Active Directory Domain Services query failed.
trans-unit.target: Either the rule is no longer valid, or the Active Directory Domain Services query failed.

trans-unit.source: An authorization rule is usually not valid in scenarios where the gateway server was at one time in a workgroup, but was later joined to a domain.
trans-unit.target: An authorization rule is usually not valid in scenarios where the gateway server was at one time in a workgroup, but was later joined to a domain.

trans-unit.source: Cannot sign in to a target computer that has been specified in authorization rules as an IPv6 address with a domain.
trans-unit.target: Cannot sign in to a target computer that has been specified in authorization rules as an IPv6 address with a domain.

trans-unit.source: Authorization rules do not support an IPv6 address in form of a domain name.
trans-unit.target: Authorization rules do not support an IPv6 address in form of a domain name.

trans-unit.source: To specify a destination computer by using an IPv6 address, use the original IPv6 address (that contains colons) in the authorization rule.
trans-unit.target: To specify a destination computer by using an IPv6 address, use the original IPv6 address (that contains colons) in the authorization rule.

trans-unit.source: Both domain and numerical (with colons) IPv6 addresses are supported as the target computer name on the Windows PowerShell Web Access sign-in page, but not in authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: Both domain and numerical (with colons) IPv6 addresses are supported as the target computer name on the Windows PowerShell Web Access sign-in page, but not in authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: For more information about IPv6 addresses, see How IPv6 Works.
trans-unit.target: For more information about IPv6 addresses, see How IPv6 Works.

trans-unit.target: See Also

trans-unit.target: [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx) [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx) [about_Remote_Requirements](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dd315349.aspx)
